message: We love statsd around here.
http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2268466
http://www.monkinetic.com/2011/02/python-statsd-server.html
though the server implementation is from Joshua Frederick (jfred on github, twitter)
I've been playing with this -- trying to figure out if the blocking socket has any downsides compared to an event loop solution
(so far, I don't see any - it's UDP on a single socket - so recvfrom will get a single datagram each time. As long as the processing doesn't take long, it should be ok... I think)
the middleware was just for logging stuff that's outside an app - like request and response times.
but the "no-remote" thing made it a no-go
:D awesome! which posts are your favorite?
Hah, I saw he had a few recent gists! I was wondering :)
hi @kastner! Joshua is alos working on a wsgi middleware that uses the client. Something like this: https://gist.github.com/846449
Or is this more like (from inside the app) remote_call('/path/to/logging/stat-name')? This is how I approached it for a client - but that was so I could log from ASP :)

it's a philosophical question :) We tend to try to keep things as stock/vanilla/boring as possible. For a varnish type thing, we'd probably use the normal logging and post-process them with our "logster" system (not OSS yet ;) but its similar to ganglia-logtailer http://codeascraft.etsy.com/2010/12/08/track-every-release/#comment-883)
heh
i actually applied to etsy, largely based on the codeascraft blog
end of last year
What advantage does a middleware have for this use case? You'd be batching your calls up (which is better for the server), but you're separating the action from the logging.
putting the client in the middleware, not the server.
does varnish have hooks for that sort of thing? or would you use the cache's own logging/stats?
you'd still run the client in-app for app-specific stats (logins, actions in-app, etc)
(as a developer a lt of this devops stuff is new to me)
I figured it was the client - was just wondering about the use case :) timing response times is a really good use!
@kastner - how would you handle logging stats for stuff served from a cache like varnish?
gotcha
Honestly, I read them all; it's the whole mentality I'm learning
we have a saying: "We work hard to be able to be this dumb." :)
(the correct answer is "The deployinator post - Quantum Of Deployment" Changed my entire life) ;) j/k
oh, um, then... that one!
FYI, Jsocol at Mozilla did a nice daemonization of the pystatsd server
Github.com/sivy/py-statsd
